Several [public-key cryptography](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public-key_cryptography "Public-key cryptography") algorithms, such as [RSA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RSA_(algorithm) "RSA (algorithm)") and the [Diffie–Hellman key exchange](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diffie%E2%80%93Hellman_key_exchange "Diffie–Hellman key exchange"), are based on large prime numbers (2048-[bit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bit "Bit") primes are common).[[159]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number#cite_note-164) RSA relies on the assumption that it is much easier (that is, more efficient) to perform the multiplication of two (large) numbers ⁠x{\displaystyle x}![Image 257: {\displaystyle x}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/87f9e315fd7e2ba406057a97300593c4802b53e4)⁠ and ⁠y{\displaystyle y}![Image 258: {\displaystyle y}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/b8a6208ec717213d4317e666f1ae872e00620a0d)⁠ than to calculate ⁠x{\displaystyle x}![Image 259: {\displaystyle x}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/87f9e315fd7e2ba406057a97300593c4802b53e4)⁠ and ⁠y{\displaystyle y}![Image 260: {\displaystyle y}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/b8a6208ec717213d4317e666f1ae872e00620a0d)⁠ (assumed [coprime](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coprime "Coprime")) if only the product x y{\displaystyle xy}![Image 261: {\displaystyle xy}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/c72eb345e496513fb8b2fa4aa8c4d89b855f9a01) is known.[[33]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number#cite_note-ent-7-35) The Diffie–Hellman key exchange relies on the fact that there are efficient algorithms for [modular exponentiation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modular_exponentiation "Modular exponentiation") (computing ⁠a b mod c{\displaystyle a^{b}{\bmod {c}}}![Image 262: {\displaystyle a^{b}{\bmod {c}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/7cdcfa653d33b1ef6fa21a5a5fc365f6a7e0dea0)⁠), while the reverse operation (the [discrete logarithm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discrete_logarithm "Discrete logarithm")) is thought to be a hard problem.[[160]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number#cite_note-165)

Prime numbers are frequently used for [hash tables](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hash_table "Hash table"). For instance the original method of Carter and Wegman for [universal hashing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universal_hashing "Universal hashing") was based on computing [hash functions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hash_function "Hash function") by choosing random [linear functions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_function "Linear function") modulo large prime numbers. Carter and Wegman generalized this method to [⁠k{\displaystyle k}![Image 263: {\displaystyle k}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/c3c9a2c7b599b37105512c5d570edc034056dd40)⁠-independent hashing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/K-independent_hashing "K-independent hashing") by using higher-degree polynomials, again modulo large primes.[[161]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number#cite_note-166) As well as in the hash function, prime numbers are used for the hash table size in [quadratic probing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quadratic_probing "Quadratic probing") based hash tables to ensure that the probe sequence covers the whole table.[[162]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number#cite_note-167)

Some [checksum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Checksum "Checksum") methods are based on the mathematics of prime numbers. For instance the checksums used in [International Standard Book Numbers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number "International Standard Book Number") are defined by taking the rest of the number modulo 11, a prime number. Because 11 is prime this method can detect both single-digit errors and transpositions of adjacent digits.[[163]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number#cite_note-168) Another checksum method, [Adler-32](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adler-32 "Adler-32"), uses arithmetic modulo 65521, the largest prime number less than ⁠2 16{\displaystyle 2^{16}}![Image 264: {\displaystyle 2^{16}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/e8e0dd3c0e42794174d2dbcb9a3ee2c6d69299d4)⁠.[[164]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number#cite_note-169) Prime numbers are also used in [pseudorandom number generators](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pseudorandom_number_generator "Pseudorandom number generator") including [linear congruential generators](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_congruential_generator "Linear congruential generator")[[165]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number#cite_note-170) and the [Mersenne Twister](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mersenne_Twister "Mersenne Twister").[[166]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number#cite_note-171)

triples.sentence: RSA relies on the assumption that it is much easier (that is, more efficient) to perform the multiplication of two (large) numbers ⁠x{\displaystyle x}![Image 257: {"displaystyle x}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/87f9e315fd7e2ba406057a97300593c4802b53e4)⁠ and ⁠y{\displaystyle y}![Image 258: {"displaystyle y}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/b8a6208ec717213d4317e666f1ae872e00620a0d)⁠ than to calculate ⁠x{\displaystyle x}![Image 259: {"displaystyle x}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/87f9e315fd7e2ba406057a97300593c4802b53e4)⁠ and ⁠y{\displaystyle y}![Image 260: {"displaystyle y}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/b8a6208ec717213d4317e666f1ae872e00620a0d)⁠ (assumed [coprime](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coprime "Coprime")) if only the product x y{\displaystyle xy}![Image 261: {"displaystyle xy}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/c72eb345e496513fb8b2fa4aa8c4d89b855f9a01) is known.[[33]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number#cite_note-ent-7-35)
triples.statement: The RSA algorithm's security is based on the principle that multiplying two large numbers is much easier than factoring their product to find the original numbers.

triples.sentence: The Diffie–Hellman key exchange relies on the fact that there are efficient algorithms for [modular exponentiation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modular_exponentiation "Modular exponentiation") (computing ⁠a b mod c{\displaystyle a^{b}{\bmod {c}}}![Image 262: {"displaystyle a^{b}{\bmod {c}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/7cdcfa653d33b1ef6fa21a5a5fc365f6a7e0dea0)⁠), while the reverse operation (the [discrete logarithm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discrete_logarithm "Discrete logarithm")) is thought to be a hard problem.[[160]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number#cite_note-165)
triples.statement: The Diffie–Hellman key exchange is secure because modular exponentiation is efficient, whereas its inverse operation, the discrete logarithm, is considered a difficult problem.

triples.sentence: Carter and Wegman generalized this method to [⁠k{\displaystyle k}![Image 263: {"displaystyle k}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/c3c9a2c7b599b37105512c5d570edc034056dd40)⁠-independent hashing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/K-independent_hashing "K-independent hashing") by using higher-degree polynomials, again modulo large primes.[[161]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number#cite_note-166)
triples.statement: The universal hashing method was generalized by Carter and Wegman to k-independent hashing by using higher-degree polynomials modulo large primes.

triples.sentence: As well as in the hash function, prime numbers are used for the hash table size in [quadratic probing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quadratic_probing "Quadratic probing") based hash tables to ensure that the probe sequence covers the whole table.[[162]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number#cite_note-167)
triples.statement: In hash tables that use quadratic probing, prime numbers are used for the table size to ensure the probe sequence covers the entire table.

triples.sentence: Prime numbers are also used in [pseudorandom number generators](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pseudorandom_number_generator "Pseudorandom number generator") including [linear congruential generators](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_congruential_generator "Linear congruential generator")[[165]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number#cite_note-170) and the [Mersenne Twister](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mersenne_Twister "Mersenne Twister").[[166]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number#cite_note-171)
triples.statement: Prime numbers are utilized in pseudorandom number generators such as linear congruential generators and the Mersenne Twister.

section_body:
Prime numbers are of central importance to number theory but also have many applications to other areas within mathematics, including [abstract algebra](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abstract_algebra "Abstract algebra") and elementary geometry. For example, it is possible to place prime numbers of points in a two-dimensional grid so that [no three are in a line](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/No-three-in-line_problem "No-three-in-line problem"), or so that every triangle formed by three of the points [has large area](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heilbronn_triangle_problem "Heilbronn triangle problem").[[167]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number#cite_note-172) Another example is [Eisenstein's criterion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eisenstein%27s_criterion "Eisenstein's criterion"), a test for whether a [polynomial is irreducible](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Irreducible_polynomial "Irreducible polynomial") based on divisibility of its coefficients by a prime number and its square.[[168]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number#cite_note-173)

[![Image 265](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Sum_of_knots3.svg/250px-Sum_of_knots3.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Sum_of_knots3.svg)

The connected sum of two prime knots

The concept of a prime number is so important that it has been generalized in different ways in various branches of mathematics. Generally, "prime" indicates minimality or indecomposability, in an appropriate sense. For example, the [prime field](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_field "Prime field") of a given field is its smallest subfield that contains both 0 and 1. It is either the field of rational numbers or a [finite field](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Finite_field "Finite field") with a prime number of elements, whence the name.[[169]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number#cite_note-174) Often a second, additional meaning is intended by using the word prime, namely that any object can be, essentially uniquely, decomposed into its prime components. For example, in [knot theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knot_theory "Knot theory"), a [prime knot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_knot "Prime knot") is a [knot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knot_(mathematics) "Knot (mathematics)") that is indecomposable in the sense that it cannot be written as the [connected sum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Connected_sum "Connected sum") of two nontrivial knots. Any knot can be uniquely expressed as a connected sum of prime knots.[[170]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number#cite_note-175) The [prime decomposition of 3-manifolds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_decomposition_(3-manifold) "Prime decomposition (3-manifold)") is another example of this type.[[171]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number#cite_note-176)

Beyond mathematics and computing, prime numbers have potential connections to [quantum mechanics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_mechanics "Quantum mechanics"), and have been used metaphorically in the arts and literature. They have also been used in [evolutionary biology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_biology "Evolutionary biology") to explain the life cycles of [cicadas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cicada "Cicada").

triples.sentence: For example, it is possible to place prime numbers of points in a two-dimensional grid so that [no three are in a line](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/No-three-in-line_problem "No-three-in-line problem"), or so that every triangle formed by three of the points [has large area](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heilbronn_triangle_problem "Heilbronn triangle problem").[[167]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number#cite_note-172)
triples.statement: It is possible to arrange a prime number of points in a two-dimensional grid so that no three are in a line, or so that any triangle formed by three points has a large area.

triples.sentence: It is either the field of rational numbers or a [finite field](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Finite_field "Finite field") with a prime number of elements, whence the name.[[169]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number#cite_note-174)
triples.statement: A prime field is either the field of rational numbers or a finite field with a prime number of elements.

triples.sentence: Any knot can be uniquely expressed as a connected sum of prime knots.[[170]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number#cite_note-175)
triples.statement: Any knot can be uniquely expressed as a connected sum of prime knots.

triples.sentence: The [prime decomposition of 3-manifolds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_decomposition_(3-manifold) "Prime decomposition (3-manifold)") is another example of this type.[[171]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number#cite_note-176)
triples.statement: The prime decomposition of 3-manifolds is another example of unique decomposition into prime components.

It is possible to partition any convex polygon into ⁠n{\displaystyle n}![Image 275: {\displaystyle n}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/a601995d55609f2d9f5e233e36fbe9ea26011b3b)⁠ smaller convex polygons of equal area and equal perimeter, when ⁠n{\displaystyle n}![Image 276: {\displaystyle n}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/a601995d55609f2d9f5e233e36fbe9ea26011b3b)⁠ is a [power of a prime number](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_power "Prime power"), but this is not known for other values of ⁠n{\displaystyle n}![Image 277: {\displaystyle n}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/a601995d55609f2d9f5e233e36fbe9ea26011b3b)⁠.[[176]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number#cite_note-181)

triples.sentence:
[Fermat primes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fermat_prime "Fermat prime") are primes of the form

F k=2 2 k+1,{\displaystyle F_{k}=2^{2^{k}}+1,}![Image 267: {\displaystyle F_{k}=2^{2^{k}}+1,}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/3cc6edcaa62bbd72af19a441f8cdba0629f37eb0)
with ⁠k{\displaystyle k}![Image 268: {\displaystyle k}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/c3c9a2c7b599b37105512c5d570edc034056dd40)⁠ a [nonnegative integer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonnegative_integer "Nonnegative integer").[[172]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number#cite_note-177)
triples.statement: Fermat primes are prime numbers of the form F_k = 2^(2^k) + 1, where k is a nonnegative integer.

triples.sentence: The first five of these numbers – 3, 5, 17, 257, and 65,537 – are prime,[[173]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number#cite_note-kls-178) but F 5{\displaystyle F_{5}}![Image 269: {\displaystyle F_{5}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/c64647603e8358bf2b07099963d5ac2d8b75ee9a) is composite and so are all other Fermat numbers that have been verified as of 2017.[[174]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number#cite_note-179)
triples.statement: The first five Fermat numbers (3, 5, 17, 257, and 65,537) are prime, but the sixth, F_5, is composite, as are all other Fermat numbers verified as of 2017.

triples.sentence: A [regular ⁠n{\displaystyle n}![Image 270: {\displaystyle n}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/a601995d55609f2d9f5e233e36fbe9ea26011b3b)⁠-gon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regular_polygon "Regular polygon") is [constructible using straightedge and compass](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constructible_polygon "Constructible polygon") if and only if the odd prime factors of ⁠n{\displaystyle n}![Image 271: {\displaystyle n}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/a601995d55609f2d9f5e233e36fbe9ea26011b3b)⁠ (if any) are distinct Fermat primes.[[173]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number#cite_note-kls-178)
triples.statement: A regular n-gon is constructible using a straightedge and compass if and only if its odd prime factors, if any, are distinct Fermat primes.

triples.sentence: Likewise, a regular ⁠n{\displaystyle n}![Image 272: {\displaystyle n}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/a601995d55609f2d9f5e233e36fbe9ea26011b3b)⁠-gon may be constructed using straightedge, compass, and an [angle trisector](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Angle_trisection "Angle trisection") if and only if the prime factors of [⁠n{\displaystyle n}![Image 273: {\displaystyle n}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/a601995d55609f2d9f5e233e36fbe9ea26011b3b)⁠](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regular_polygon "Regular polygon") are any number of copies of 2 or 3 together with a (possibly empty) set of distinct [Pierpont primes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pierpont_prime "Pierpont prime"), primes of the form ⁠2 a 3 b+1{\displaystyle 2^{a}3^{b}+1}![Image 274: {\displaystyle 2^{a}3^{b}+1}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/d06f1cc50f358fed2f88c9789d2a15fc5c003dc5)⁠.[[175]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number#cite_note-180)
triples.statement: A regular n-gon can be constructed with a straightedge, compass, and an angle trisector if and only if its prime factors are any number of 2s or 3s, along with a possibly empty set of distinct Pierpont primes, which are primes of the form 2^a * 3^b + 1.

triples.sentence: It is possible to partition any convex polygon into ⁠n{\displaystyle n}![Image 275: {\displaystyle n}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/a601995d55609f2d9f5e233e36fbe9ea26011b3b)⁠ smaller convex polygons of equal area and equal perimeter, when ⁠n{\displaystyle n}![Image 276: {\displaystyle n}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/a601995d55609f2d9f5e233e36fbe9ea26011b3b)⁠ is a [power of a prime number](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_power "Prime power"), but this is not known for other values of ⁠n{\displaystyle n}![Image 277: {\displaystyle n}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/a601995d55609f2d9f5e233e36fbe9ea26011b3b)⁠.[[176]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number#cite_note-181)
triples.statement: It is possible to partition any convex polygon into n smaller convex polygons of equal area and perimeter when n is a power of a prime number, but this is not known for other values of n.

section_body: Beginning with the work of [Hugh Montgomery](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hugh_Lowell_Montgomery "Hugh Lowell Montgomery") and [Freeman Dyson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freeman_Dyson "Freeman Dyson") in the 1970s, mathematicians and physicists have speculated that the zeros of the Riemann zeta function are connected to the energy levels of [quantum systems](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_system "Quantum system").[[177]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number#cite_note-182)[[178]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number#cite_note-183) Prime numbers are also significant in [quantum information science](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_information_science "Quantum information science"), thanks to mathematical structures such as [mutually unbiased bases](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutually_unbiased_bases "Mutually unbiased bases") and [symmetric informationally complete positive-operator-valued measures](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SIC-POVM "SIC-POVM").[[179]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number#cite_note-184)[[180]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number#cite_note-185)

triples.statement: Beginning with the work of Hugh Montgomery and Freeman Dyson in the 1970s, mathematicians and physicists have speculated that the zeros of the Riemann zeta function are connected to the energy levels of quantum systems.

triples.statement: Prime numbers are significant in quantum information science due to mathematical structures like mutually unbiased bases and symmetric informationally complete positive-operator-valued measures.

section_body: The evolutionary strategy used by [cicadas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cicada "Cicada") of the genus _[Magicicada](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magicicada "Magicicada")_ makes use of prime numbers.[[181]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number#cite_note-186) These insects spend most of their lives as [grubs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Larva "Larva") underground. They only pupate and then emerge from their burrows after 7, 13 or 17 years, at which point they fly about, breed, and then die after a few weeks at most. Biologists theorize that these prime-numbered breeding cycle lengths have evolved in order to prevent predators from synchronizing with these cycles.[[182]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number#cite_note-187)[[183]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number#cite_note-188) In contrast, the multi-year periods between flowering in [bamboo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bamboo "Bamboo") plants are hypothesized to be [smooth numbers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smooth_number "Smooth number"), having only small prime numbers in their factorizations.[[184]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number#cite_note-189)

triples.sentence: The evolutionary strategy used by [cicadas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cicada "Cicada") of the genus _[Magicicada](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magicicada "Magicicada")_ makes use of prime numbers.[[181]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number#cite_note-186)
triples.statement: The evolutionary strategy of Magicicada cicadas utilizes prime numbers.

section_body:
Prime numbers have influenced many artists and writers. The French [composer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Composer "Composer")[Olivier Messiaen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olivier_Messiaen "Olivier Messiaen") used prime numbers to create ametrical music through "natural phenomena". In works such as _[La Nativité du Seigneur](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/La\_Nativit%C3%A9\_du\_Seigneur "La Nativité du Seigneur")_ (1935) and _[Quatre études de rythme](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quatre\_%C3%A9tudes\_de\_rythme "Quatre études de rythme")_ (1949–1950), he simultaneously employs motifs with lengths given by different prime numbers to create unpredictable rhythms: the primes 41, 43, 47 and 53 appear in the third étude, "Neumes rythmiques". According to Messiaen this way of composing was "inspired by the movements of nature, movements of free and unequal durations".[[185]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number#cite_note-190)

In his science fiction novel _[Contact](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contact\_(novel) "Contact (novel)")_, scientist [Carl Sagan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Sagan "Carl Sagan") suggested that prime factorization could be used as a means of establishing two-dimensional image planes in communications with aliens, an idea that he had first developed informally with American astronomer [Frank Drake](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frank_Drake "Frank Drake") in 1975.[[186]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number#cite_note-191) In the novel _[The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_Curious\_Incident\_of\_the\_Dog\_in\_the\_Night-Time "The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time")_ by [Mark Haddon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mark_Haddon "Mark Haddon"), the narrator arranges the sections of the story by consecutive prime numbers as a way to convey the mental state of its main character, a mathematically gifted teen with [Asperger syndrome](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asperger_syndrome "Asperger syndrome").[[187]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number#cite_note-192) Prime numbers are used as a metaphor for loneliness and isolation in the [Paolo Giordano](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paolo_Giordano "Paolo Giordano") novel _[The Solitude of Prime Numbers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_Solitude\_of\_Prime\_Numbers\_(novel) "The Solitude of Prime Numbers (novel)")_, in which they are portrayed as "outsiders" among integers.[[188]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number#cite_note-193)

triples.sentence: According to Messiaen this way of composing was "inspired by the movements of nature, movements of free and unequal durations".[[185]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number#cite_note-190)
triples.statement: According to Olivier Messiaen, this method of composing was "inspired by the movements of nature, movements of free and unequal durations".
